content.question:
Reaction 1: 

<math alttext="F e O solid plus C O gas react to produce F e liquid plus C O 2 gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FeO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>CO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is greater than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> 

Reaction 2: 

<math alttext="C solid plus C O 2 gas react to produce 2 C O gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>CO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> 

Overall reaction: 

<math alttext="F e O solid plus C solid react to produce F e liquid plus C O gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FeO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>CO</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> 

The chemical equations above represent the main reactions that occur during the production of <math alttext="F e liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> under certain conditions. The overall reaction couples reactions 1 and 2, resulting in a thermodynamically favorable process. Which of the following best explains whether or not a particle diagram could represent how the coupling of reaction 1 and reaction 2 results in <math alttext="delta G naught of reaction is less than 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: A particle diagram that represents the increase in the volume of gaseous product particles would be a good representation of how the coupling of reactions 1 and 2 results in a thermodynamically favorable process.

A particle diagram that represents the decrease in the average kinetic energy of the particles would be a good representation of how the coupling of reactions 1 and 2 results in a thermodynamically favorable process.

A particle diagram cannot represent how the changes in energy that take place as reaction 1 occurs are more than offset by the changes in energy taking place as reaction 2 occurs, resulting in a thermodynamically favorable overall reaction.
A particle diagram cannot represent the changes in the amount of matter that take place as reaction 1 is coupled to reaction 2, resulting in a thermodynamically favorable overall reaction.

content.answer: A particle diagram cannot represent how the changes in energy that take place as reaction 1 occurs are more than offset by the changes in energy taking place as reaction 2 occurs, resulting in a thermodynamically favorable overall reaction.

skill.text: 4.D: Explain the degree to which a model or representation describes the connection between particulate-level properties and macroscopic properties.
